children.name: a piece of work have to be done
job
children.definition: nhiệm vụ, công việc

children.name: task
children.definition: formal a piece of work that you have to do - use this especially about a difficult or unpleasant job, or about a specific regular part of your work: nhiệm vụ
examples: One of the first tasks Eva set herself was learning the local language.

children.name: have the task of doing something
examples: He had the task of judging the competition.

children.name: carry out/perform/do a task
examples: I don't think we have enough resources to carry out this task.

children.name: set/give somebody a task
examples: I was given the task of writing the chairman's speech.

children.name: take on/undertake a task
examples: No-one else is willing to take on the task.

children.name: assign a task
children.definition: give someone a task to do
examples: People were assigned different tasks.

children.name: a task faces somebody
examples: Given the nature of the task facing us, three days might not be enough.

children.name: impossible
examples: She may argue that the task is impossible.

children.name: simple
examples: The children help with simple tasks like carrying in water or logs for the fire.

children.name: difficult
examples: The task of selecting just five candidates is difficult.

children.name: somebody's first/main task
examples: Their first task was to rebuild the wall.

children.name: a thankless task
children.definition: a difficult but necessary job
examples: Driving a bus in London must be a pretty thankless task.

children.name: a formidable/daunting task
children.definition: very difficult
examples: Achieving these targets will be a formidable task.

children.name: an unenviable task
children.definition: unpleasant or difficult
examples: He has the unenviable task of telling hungry people that there is no food.

children.name: an arduous task
children.definition: needing a lot of effort and hard work
examples: We began the arduous task of carrying the furniture to the top floor.

children.name: sth is not an easy task/ sth is no easy task
children.definition: sth is difficult
examples: Recruiting experienced people is no easy task nowadays.

children.name: task of
examples: The task of the union representative is to fight on behalf of the members.
RegisterIn everyday English, people usually sayjobrather thantask:

children.name: sth to do
children.definition: / some work to do a job that you have to do, either for your work or for yourself, especially things that you have to leave your office or house to do:
examples: I’ll pick the laundry up on Saturday -- I have some shopping to do anyway.
I’ve got some work to do this evening.

children.name: piece of work
children.definition: sth that you have to do, especially sth that involves writing or drawing and a lot of thinking: công việc

children.name: do/hand in/submit a piece of work
examples: Do you actually fail the year if you don’t hand in a piece of work?
I’ve got a merit for every piece of work I’ve done.

children.name: good/excellent etc piece of work
examples: I think this is a very fine piece of work and it deserves a first class mark.

children.name: Look at that piece of work and ask yourself the question -- ‘Is this the best I can do?’
assignment
children.definition: 1 a piece of work that is given to sb as part of their job : nhiệm vụ, bổn phẩn
examples: Bart’s first assignment for the newspaper was to report on the French elections.
This is a really tough assignment, and I believe you’re the only person who can handle it.
on an assignment
She’s gone to Italy on a special assignment.
on assignment
He was killed while on assignment abroad.
2[C] a piece of work that a student is asked to do : nhiệm vụ, bổn phẩn
a history assignment
finish/complete an assignmenthoàn thành nhiệm vụ
She stayed late to complete a class assignment.
history/homework/school/military etc assignment
Robin spent many lunch hours poring over her math assignments.
I eventually got a teaching assignment at Xibei.
one-year/two week etc assignment
I figure this will either make or break us,’ Cheyne said of the 1-year assignment to get the camp up and running.

children.name: chore
children.definition: an unpleasant or boring job, especially one that you have to do regularly in your home: công việc

children.name: a household chore
children.definition: a chore in the home
examples: household chores such as washing and ironing clothes

children.name: a daily/everyday chore
examples: When you're working it can be hard to find time for the daily chores.

children.name: a domestic chore
children.definition: a chore such as cleaning or putting things away
examples: Everyone in the flat shared the cooking and domestic chores.

children.name: an administrative chore
children.definition: a chore such as writing letters or paying bills
examples: filling in forms and other administrative chores

children.name: routine chores
children.definition: done regularly
examples: Who does most of the routine chores in your house?

children.name: mundane chores
children.definition: ordinary and uninteresting
examples: the mundane chores of everyday life

children.name: do the chores
examples: I stayed at home and did the chores.

children.name: perform/carry out a choreformal
children.definition: do a chore
examples: It's good for kids to learn how to perform household chores.

children.name: go about your chores
children.definition: do your chores
examples: I got up and went about my chores, feeding the cats and making tea.

children.name: help with the chores
examples: All their children help with the chores.

children.name: everyday chores like shopping and housework
examples: We share the domestic chores.

children.name: errand
children.definition: a small job that you need to do or that sb has asked you to do, such as buying sth, posting sth, taking sb to a place etc: việc lặt vặt (ai sai khiến nhờ vả)

children.name: do/run an errand (for sth)
examples: Before you disappear, I want you to do an errand for me.
Peter cleaned equipment, ran errands, answered the phone -- it was all routine.
I used to pick up her dry cleaning and run errands for her.

children.name: duty
children.definition: something that you have a responsibility to do, especially as a regular part of your job - used especially in contracts or other official documents:: nhiệm vụ
examples: Martin’s duties included cleaning the cars.
She works for her father doing part-time secretarial duties.

children.name: carry out your duties
children.definition: alsoperform/discharge your dutiesformal
examples: (= do your job )She has always carried out her duties efficiently.

children.name: take up your duties
children.definition: start doing a new job
examples: Neale has agreed a three-year contract and takes up his duties on March 1.

children.name: resume your duties
children.definition: start doing your job again
examples: She hopes to be well enough to resume her duties next week.

children.name: report for duty
children.definition: arrive and be ready to start work
examples: You must report for duty at 8:30 tomorrow morning.

children.name: neglect/shirk your duties
children.definition: not do your job properly
examples: No soldier can be allowed to neglect his duties.

children.name: official duties
examples: The new President will take up his official duties next month.

children.name: presidential/royal/ministerial etc duties
children.definition: duties that go with being a president, member of a royal family, a minister etc
examples: The prince is now old enough to carry out royal duties.

children.name: household/domestic duties
children.definition: jobs you have to do around the house
examples: My husband and I share most of the household duties.

children.name: light duties
children.definition: not involving hard physical work
examples: He'd been wounded, sent home and put on light duties.

children.name: guard duty
children.definition: job of guarding a place
examples: There were two soldiers on guard duty outside the embassy.

children.name: neglect of duty
children.definition: failing to do your job properly
examples: Six police officers were fired for neglect of duty.

children.name: a tour of duty
children.definition: period of working in another country as a soldier, government officer etc
examples: He became a General, and his tours of duty included Korea and Vietnam.

children.name: beyond the call of duty
children.definition: more than you have to do as part of your job
examples: She's a doctor who has gone beyond the call of duty in her care for her patients.

children.name: in the course of duty
children.definition: while doing your job, especially for your country
examples: Stewart received a medal for outstanding bravery in the course of duty.

children.name: sb’s duties
examples: As soon as she returned home from her honeymoon, she resumed her medical duties at the clinic.

children.name: have a duty to do sthformal
examples: Teachers have a duty to ensure that students are not injured whilst they are in their care.

children.name: go about /fulfil duties
examples: She is a member of staff, and like all of us, she has duties to fulfil.
I admired him, especially because of the way he went about his duties efficiently.

children.name: suspend sb/relieve sb from dutiesto stop them doing their job for a period of time : tạm thời cho nghỉ việc
examples: Three instructors have been suspended from duties while sexual harassment charges are investigated.
Nine officers were relieved of their duties after McDuffie’s death.

children.name: work that sb does as part of their job
work
children.definition: the things that you have to do in your job, which needtime and effort: công việc, việc làm
examples: What kind of work are you looking for?
He liked the work, and he was good at it too.

children.name: do some/more etc work
examples: Scott’s doing some work for me at the moment, as it happens.
I didn’t get much work done today.
Being in the police isn’t all action. Administration is a large part of the work we do.

children.name: personnel/secretarial/bar etc work
examples: Have you ever done bar work before?
He’s doing construction work these days.
It’s clerical work mainly -- pretty boring.

children.name: voluntary/charity workwork that you do not get paid for : công việc tình nguyên / từ thiện
examples: She does two afternoons voluntary work at the playgroup.
Are you still involved in charity work?

children.name: extra/more/additional work
examples: The last thing I want is extra work.

children.name: business
children.definition: work that you do as part of your job :
examples: Hi Maggie! Is this phone callbusiness or pleasure?
usefulbusiness contacts
on businessfor business, not pleasure
I have to go to Tokyo next month on business.
She’s in New York this weekon business(= for her work ).
business trip/meeting/traveller etc
We discussed the idea over a business lunch.

children.name: project
children.definition: an important piece of work that an organization, group, or person plans carefully in order to achieve a particular aim over a long period of time: dự án
examples: The project aims to provide an analysis of children’s emotions.
project to do sth
a project to develop a substitute for oil
The project is funded by Wellcome plc.

children.name: a research project
examples: The aim of this research project is to study modern food habits.

children.name: a construction project
examples: Spending on new construction projects has been reduced.

children.name: a development project
examples: Our aim is assess the environmental impact of new development projects.

children.name: a pilot project
children.definition: one organized to test if an idea will be successful
examples: These changes were shelved after pilot projects showed poor results.

children.name: a major project
examples: The company is funding a major research project into the causes of addiction.

children.name: an ambitious project
examples: Young people often enjoy the challenge of an ambitious project.

children.name: successful
examples: Was the project successful?

children.name: work on a project
examples: A team has been working on the project for three years.

children.name: be involved in a project
examples: I am involved in various projects.

children.name: set up a project
children.definition: organize it
examples: $30 million would be required to set up the project.

children.name: embark on a project
children.definition: start it
examples: He was embarking on the biggest project of his career.

children.name: complete a project
examples: The project was completed on time.

children.name: a project manager/leader
examples: The project manager is responsible for sorting this out.

children.name: a phase/stage of a project
examples: The first phase of the project was due to be completed by the end of 2008.

children.name: mission
children.definition: an important job that sb has been given to do, especially when they are sent to another place :
examples: Her mission was to improve staff morale.
on a mission
scientists on a mission to the rainforest, to study possible medicinal uses of plants
rescue/diplomatic/fact-finding etc mission
a group of US congressmen on a fact-finding mission to Northern Ireland

children.name: undertaking
children.definition: a big or important job, which you decide or agree to do, and which you will be responsible for: công cuộc
examples: Starting a new business can be a risky undertaking.

children.name: huge/major/big etc undertaking
examples: In the late 1980s, the US embarked on a major undertaking:the human genome project.
Everybody needs to realise that this is a huge undertaking.
Covering an Olympics is an extraordinary undertaking for any television company.

children.name: work that you have to do in your home
housework
children.definition: work that needs to be done in your home, for example, cleaning, washing clothes, or keeping rooms tidy: việc nhà
examples: None of her kids ever help with the housework.
I’ve got to catch up on the housework this weekend.

children.name: do housework
examples: Well, I did all my housework this morning, though you wouldn’t think it to look at the place now.

children.name: work
children.definition: the things that you have to do in your home, for yourself or your family: việc ( nhà )
examples: The garden needs a bit more work, but it’s almost finished.
Use the best tools and materials you can afford to give a professional finish to your DIY work.
do some/any more/a bit of etc work
‘Where’s Dave?’ ‘He’s outside, doing some work on the car, I think.’
work on
I’m not doing any more work on the house this year, I can’t be bothered.

children.name: slog
children.definition: be a  UK use this to say that work is difficult, boring, and tiring: công việc vất vả
examples: The journey across the valley to the farm is going to be a slog.

children.name: hard/long slog
examples: It’s a hard slog isn’t it? I wish we’d got further yesterday.
Cutting all the wood before nightfall was a long, hard slog.

children.name: grind
children.definition: things that you have to do every day, especially as part of your job, which are boring and make you feel tired: công việc

children.name: grind of
examples: Work feels like such a grind lately.
The relentless grind of hard labour and ill-health had taken its toll on Booth.

children.name: the daily grind
examples: The daily grind of meetings and tutorials went on.

children.name: hard grindBritish
examples: The Prime Minister is pictured taking a break from the hard grind of political life.

children.name: donkey work
children.definition: UK /grunt workUS  informal work that is boring or takes a lot of time and effort, but that has to be done as part of a job or larger piece of work: công việc nặng nhọc ( do nhàm chán, mất nhiều công sức )
examples: I was doing grunt work for the secretary in the department, twenty hours a week.
The real donkey work was actually done by those guys.

children.name: drudgery
children.definition: work that is hard and unpleasant because it is very boring, takes a long time to do, and often involves a lot of physical effort: công việc nặng nhọc
examples: Technological advances have taken much of the drudgery out of the assembly line and car plant.
What seemed a promising job turned into months of boredom and drudgery.

children.name: the drudgery of sth
examples: The data management system has eliminated much of the drudgery of filing.
Calculators were introduced to relieve students of the drudgery of pencil-and-paper number-crunching.

children.name: toil
children.definition: formal difficult and boring work that takes a long time: công việc vất vả, cực nhọc
examples: Here began their arduous toil to force a living from the land.

children.name: man’s desire for freedom from physical toil
work
children.definition: when you use physical or mental effort in order to achieve sth
examples: Looking after children can be hard work .

children.name: carry out work
examples: The work should be carried out without further delay.

children.name: do work
examples: He was doing some work on his father’s car.

children.name: set to/get to/get down to work
children.definition: start work
examples: They set to work cutting down trees and brushwood.

children.name: undertake work
examples: About a three adults in ten undertake voluntary work.

children.name: work starts/begins
examples: Work had already started on the bridge when the error was spotted.

children.name: work continues
examples: Work is continuing on three major building projects.

children.name: hard
examples: It’s been very hard work, but I’ve loved every moment of it.

children.name: backbreaking
children.definition: very tiring
examples: Clearing the garden was slow, backbreaking work.

children.name: arduous
children.definition: needing a lot of effort
examples: This was physically arduous work.

children.name: heavy work
children.definition: hard physical work
examples: The heavy work is done by the gardener.

children.name: light work
children.definition: work that is not physically hard
examples: He had been ill, but she found him some light work to do.

children.name: work on
examples: Work will start next month on a new swimming pool in the centre of the city.

children.name: labour
children.definition: UK /laborUS  hard physical work, such as digging, lifting, or cleaning: công việc nặng nhọc
examples: Many women do all the work in the home, and their labour is unpaid.
Marx defined the working class as people who sell their labour to employers.
The garage charges £30 an hour for labour.
Workerswithdrewtheirlabour(= protested by stopping work )for twenty-four hours.
manual/physical labourcông việc chân tay
You don’t look as if you could do physical labor.
Many women do hard manual labour
farm/agricultural labour
rising opportunities in agricultural labor in the North

children.name: labour of love
children.definition: a piece of hard work which you do because you enjoy it and not because you will receive money or praise for it, or because you need to do it
examples: He's always working on his car - it's a labour of love.
